newsitem.title: USA: Ex-employees of Michael Jackson must pay for suit.
newsitem.headline: Ex-employees of Michael Jackson must pay for suit.

text.p: A judge has ordered five former employees of singer Michael Jackson to pay nearly $1.5 million in court and attorneys' fees after they lost a wrongful dismissal suit against the self-styled "King of Pop".
"I think the fees set forth are reasonable. I am going to award them," Superior Court Judge Zell Canter said at a hearing on Wednesday in Santa Maria. Jackson was not in court.
Under California state law, the winner of a civil suit is allowed to recover some of the costs of a suit, including attorneys' fees.

The five former employees at Jackson's Neverland Ranch, near Santa Barbara, sued the star last year claiming they were forced to quit as a result of harassment, threats and being spied on by Jackson's security guards.
After a six-month trial that ended in March, the judge ruled against their claim.
In addition to the state award of court costs, the five had also signed a confidentiality agreement containing certain provisions for granting litigation costs to the winner of a potential lawsuit.

"Having contracted for this type of relief, Mr Jackson is entitled to it (collect costs) just like any other person," Jackson's lawyer Steve Cochran told reporters outside the courthouse, some 100 miles (160 km) north of Los Angeles.
"This is just the flip side of the coin of what the plaintiffs tried to do," he said.
The costs awarded to Jackson by Judge Canter totalled $1.473 million, of which $1.29 million were attorneys' fees.
